knowledges.speaker: Paul

synsets.definition: use one's feet to advance; advance by steps
_examples: Walk, don't run!
We walked instead of driving
She walks with a slight limp
The patient cannot walk yet
Walk over to the cabinet

synsets.definition: accompany or escort
_examples: I'll walk you to your car

synsets.definition: obtain a base on balls
traverse or cover by walking
_examples: Walk the tightrope
Paul walked the streets of Damascus
She walks 3 miles every day

synsets.definition: give a base on balls to
live or behave in a specified manner
_examples: walk in sadness

synsets.definition: be or act in association with
_examples: We must walk with our dispossessed brothers and sisters
Walk with God

synsets.definition: walk at a pace
_examples: The horses walked across the meadow

synsets.definition: make walk
_examples: He walks the horse up the mountain
Walk the dog twice a day

synsets.definition: take a walk; go for a walk; walk for pleasure
_examples: The lovers held hands while walking
We like to walk every Sunday

knowledges.origin_sent: Ever since she walked out on me, I, uh ...

knowledges.speaker: Monica

synsets.definition: orally recite the letters of or give the spelling of
_examples: How do you spell this word?" "We had to spell out our names for the police officer

synsets.definition: indicate or signify
_examples: I'm afraid this spells trouble!

synsets.definition: write or name the letters that comprise the conventionally accepted form of (a word or part of a word)
_examples: He spelled the word wrong in this letter

synsets.definition: relieve (someone) from work by taking a turn
_examples: She spelled her husband at the wheel

synsets.definition: place under a spell
take turns working
_examples: the workers spell every four hours

knowledges.origin_sent: What, you wanna spell it out with noodles?

knowledges.speaker: Monica

synsets.definition: have the quality of being; (copula, used with an adjective or a predicate noun)
_examples: John is rich
This is not a good answer

synsets.definition: be identical to; be someone or something
_examples: The president of the company is John Smith
This is my house

synsets.definition: occupy a certain position or area; be somewhere
_examples: Where is my umbrella?" "The toolshed is in the back
What is behind this behavior?

synsets.definition: have an existence, be extant
_examples: Is there a God?

synsets.definition: happen, occur, take place; this was during the visit to my parents' house"
_examples: I lost my wallet
There were two hundred people at his funeral
There was a lot of noise in the kitchen

synsets.definition: be identical or equivalent to
_examples: One dollar equals 1,000 rubles these days!

synsets.definition: form or compose
_examples: This money is my only income
The stone wall was the backdrop for the performance
These constitute my entire belonging
The children made up the chorus
This sum represents my entire income for a year
These few men comprise his entire army

synsets.definition: work in a specific place, with a specific subject, or in a specific function
_examples: He is a herpetologist
She is our resident philosopher

synsets.definition: represent, as of a character on stage
_examples: Derek Jacobi was Hamlet

synsets.definition: spend or use time
_examples: I may be an hour

synsets.definition: have life, be alive
_examples: Our great leader is no more
My grandfather lived until the end of war

synsets.definition: to remain unmolested, undisturbed, or uninterrupted -- used only in infinitive form
_examples: let her be

synsets.definition: be priced at
_examples: These shoes cost $100

knowledges.speaker: Monica

synsets.definition: be cognizant or aware of a fact or a specific piece of information; possess knowledge or information about
_examples: I know that the President lied to the people
I want to know who is winning the game!
I know it's time

synsets.definition: know how to do or perform something
_examples: She knows how to knit
Does your husband know how to cook?

synsets.definition: be aware of the truth of something; have a belief or faith in something; regard as true beyond any doubt
_examples: I know that I left the key on the table
Galileo knew that the earth moves around the sun

synsets.definition: be familiar or acquainted with a person or an object
_examples: She doesn't know this composer
Do you know my sister?
We know this movie
I know him under a different name
This flower is known as a Peruvian Lily

synsets.definition: have firsthand knowledge of states, situations, emotions, or sensations
_examples: I know the feeling!
have you ever known hunger?
I have lived a kind of hell when I was a drug addict
The holocaust survivors have lived a nightmare
I lived through two divorces

synsets.definition: accept (someone) to be what is claimed or accept his power and authority
_examples: The Crown Prince was acknowledged as the true heir to the throne
We do not recognize your gods

synsets.definition: have fixed in the mind
_examples: I know Latin
This student knows her irregular verbs
Do you know the poem well enough to recite it?

synsets.definition: have sexual intercourse with
_examples: This student sleeps with everyone in her dorm
Adam knew Eve
Were you ever intimate with this man?

synsets.definition: know the nature or character of
_examples: we all knew her as a big show-off

synsets.definition: be able to distinguish, recognize as being different
_examples: The child knows right from wrong

synsets.definition: perceive as familiar
_examples: I know this voice!

knowledges.origin_sent: I know being spit on is probably not what you need right now.

knowledges.origin_sent: I'm - I'm - I'm glad you smashed her watch!

knowledges.speaker: Monica

synsets.definition: hit hard
_examples: He smashed a 3-run homer

synsets.definition: break into pieces, as by striking or knocking over
_examples: Smash a plate

synsets.definition: reduce to bankruptcy
_examples: My daughter's fancy wedding is going to break me!
The slump in the financial markets smashed him

synsets.definition: hit violently
_examples: She smashed her car against the guard rail

synsets.definition: humiliate or depress completely
_examples: She was crushed by his refusal of her invitation
The death of her son smashed her

synsets.definition: damage or destroy as if by violence
_examples: The teenager banged up the car of his mother

synsets.definition: hit (a tennis ball) in a powerful overhead stroke
collide or strike violently and suddenly
_examples: The motorcycle smashed into the guard rail

synsets.definition: overthrow or destroy (something considered evil or harmful)
_examples: The police smashed the drug ring after they were tipped off

synsets.definition: break suddenly into pieces, as from a violent blow
_examples: The window smashed

knowledges.origin_sent: I'm - I'm - I'm glad you smashed her watch!

knowledges.speaker: Paul

synsets.definition: judge or regard; look upon; judge
_examples: I think he is very smart
I believe her to be very smart
I think that he is her boyfriend
The racist conceives such people to be inferior

synsets.definition: expect, believe, or suppose
_examples: I imagine she earned a lot of money with her new novel
I thought to find her in a bad state
he didn't think to find her in the kitchen
I guess she is angry at me for standing her up

synsets.definition: use or exercise the mind or one's power of reason in order to make inferences, decisions, or arrive at a solution or judgments
_examples: I've been thinking all day and getting nowhere

synsets.definition: recall knowledge from memory; have a recollection
_examples: I can't remember saying any such thing
I can't think what her last name was
can you remember her phone number?
Do you remember that he once loved you?
call up memories

synsets.definition: imagine or visualize
_examples: Just think--you could be rich one day!
Think what a scene it must have been!

synsets.definition: focus one's attention on a certain state
_examples: Think big
think thin

synsets.definition: have in mind as a purpose
_examples: I mean no harm
I only meant to help you
She didn't think to harm me
We thought to return early that night

synsets.definition: decide by pondering, reasoning, or reflecting
_examples: Can you think what to do next?

synsets.definition: ponder; reflect on, or reason about
_examples: Think the matter through
Think how hard life in Russia must be these days

synsets.definition: dispose the mind in a certain way
_examples: Do you really think so?

synsets.definition: have or formulate in the mind
_examples: think good thoughts

synsets.definition: be capable of conscious thought
_examples: Man is the only creature that thinks

synsets.definition: bring into a given condition by mental preoccupation
_examples: She thought herself into a state of panic over the final exam
